<p>
LETTER OF CREDENCE 
</p><p>
To OUR GREAT AND GOOD FRIEND His BRITANNIC MAJESTY 
</p><p>
Great and Good Friend. 
</p><p>
To testify to your Majesty the sincerity of the government of the United States in its negotiations, I have transmitted to John 
Quincy Adams, Minister Resident of the United States of America at the <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?city=hague" rel="city">Hague</a>, the Ratification of the Treaty of Amity, Commerce 
and Navigation, concluded and signed on the iQth day of November, <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1794">1794</a>, by the Plenipotentiaries of your Majesty and of the 
United States : and the said John Quincy Adams is instructed to take the necessary measures for the exchange of the Ratifications. 
I beseech your Majesty, therefore, to give full credence to whatever he shall say to you, on the part of the United States, concerning the 
same ; and to receive the said Ratification in the name of, and on the part of, the United States of America, when it shall be 
tendered by him. I pray God to have your Majesty in his holy keeping. 
</p><p>
Written at <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?city=philadelphia" rel="city">Philadelphia</a> this 25th day of August in the year of our Lord <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1795">1795</a>. 
</p><p>
(Signed) GEO. WASHINGTON. 
</p><p>
By the special command of the President of the United States. 
</p><p>
(Signed) <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=tip" rel="met co-worker">JTIMOTHY PICKERING</a>, 
at this time executing the office of Secretary of State. 
</p>
